text:
BEN WEDEMAN: It was the latest
in a long series of horrors
that is the war in Syria.

Early Tuesday morning,
the town of Khan Sheikhoun
was rocked by explosions.

And suddenly there
was pandemonium.

Hundreds, Including
many children,

struggling for breath,
foaming at the mouth.

What exactly happened
Tuesday morning isn't clear.
The result however is.

For the lucky who survived like
55-year-old Ayesha Tillawi,

now in a Turkish hospital,
the memories return.
[non-english speech]

BEN WEDEMAN: There was
an airstrike she says.
I saw a yellow and blue.
We felt dizzy and fainted.

Ahmardabda Rhahim
still has trouble

breathing or reconciling
Tuesday's events.
[non-english speech]

BEN WEDEMAN: I don't know
what happened to my children
he says.

Turkish teams in
full chemical suits

are deployed in no man's
land to wash down those
coming to Turkey for treatment.

While a Turkish mobile lab
for nuclear, biological,

and chemical weapons detection
heads across the border.

13-Year-old Mazin
Yusif, Isha's grandson,

is back on his feet
in the hospital.

But the trauma has
seared his soul.
[non-english speech]

BEN WEDEMAN: I saw the explosion
in front of my grandfather's
house he recalls.
I ran to their house barefoot.

I saw my grandfather sitting
like this, suffocated.
Then I became dizzy.

How many of his
relatives were killed?
[non-english speech]
BEN WEDEMAN: 19 he responds.
[non-english speech]
[no speech]

BEN WEDEMAN: A Syrian civil war
is now into its seventh year.

It's left hundreds of
thousands of people dead.

This was not the
first chemical attack

and it probably
won't be the last.

All these years
diplomats and politicians
have talked, and talked.
But people continue to die.

I'm Ben Wedeman, CNN on
the Turkish Syrian border.
